meta.title: German Local Business Landing Page Audit Checklist
meta.purpose: Systematic conversion optimization audit for German local service businesses

categories.name: Visual Hierarchy & Scanning Patterns
categories.description: How users visually navigate and process the page

criteria.description: Key information placed along F-pattern hotspots (top horizontal, left vertical)
howToCheck: Take screenshot and overlay F-pattern template
Logo, headline, and primary CTA should fall on F-pattern
Left margin should contain scannable headlines
First two lines should contain most important info
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Eye-tracking studies show users scan in F-pattern, spending 80% of attention on left side and top
criteria.passCriteria: 3+ key elements on F-pattern hotspots
failIndicators: Key CTAs below fold on right side

criteria.description: Core offer understandable without scrolling
howToCheck: Can you answer: What do they do? Who is it for? Why them?
Is there a clear next action visible?
Time yourself - can you understand in under 5 seconds?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Primacy effect - first impression determines engagement. 57% of users don't scroll.
criteria.passCriteria: All 3 questions answerable in 5 seconds

criteria.description: Important elements have proportionally larger visual weight
howToCheck: Squint test - blur the page, do important elements still stand out?
Size hierarchy: H1 > H2 > H3 > body
CTA button is the most visually prominent element
Hero image supports (not competes with) headline
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Visual weight creates hierarchy; larger/bolder = more important
criteria.passCriteria: Clear 3-level hierarchy visible in squint test

criteria.description: Natural visual path leads to conversion action
howToCheck: Track where your eye goes first, second, third
Does the path lead to CTA?
Are there 'dead ends' where the eye stops?
Arrows, lines, or gaze direction guiding toward CTA?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Directional cues (explicit and implicit) guide attention toward desired actions
criteria.passCriteria: Natural 3-step path ending at CTA
failIndicators: CTA not in natural eye flow

criteria.description: Strategic whitespace creates breathing room and focus
howToCheck: Is there sufficient padding around key elements?
Is the page scannable or cluttered?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Whitespace increases comprehension by 20% and draws attention to isolated elements
criteria.passCriteria: Consistent spacing, no crowded sections

criteria.description: Page doesn't overwhelm with choices or information
howToCheck: Count number of choices/links above fold (should be <7)
Is there ONE clear primary action?
Can you explain the page in one sentence?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Hick's Law - decision time increases with number of choices. Miller's Law - 7+/-2 items max.
criteria.passCriteria: 1 primary CTA, max 3 secondary options, <7 nav items

criteria.description: Messaging frames the cost of NOT acting
howToCheck: Is there mention of what they're missing/losing?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Losses are felt 2x more powerfully than equivalent gains (Kahneman)
criteria.passCriteria: At least 2 loss-framed elements present

good: Jeden Tag ohne Wallbox kostet Sie â‚¬X an Tankkosten
Nur noch 3 Termine im Januar frei

criteria.description: Testimonials/reviews placed where doubt occurs
howToCheck: Is social proof visible near CTAs?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Social proof reduces uncertainty at high-friction moments
criteria.passCriteria: Social proof within 200px of every CTA

criteria.description: Expertise and credibility clearly established
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Authority principle (Cialdini) - we trust experts and credentials
criteria.passCriteria: 3+ authority signals visible, at least 1 above fold

criteria.description: Legitimate scarcity or time-sensitivity communicated
howToCheck: Is urgency based on real constraints?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Scarcity increases perceived value, but fake urgency destroys trust
criteria.passCriteria: 1-2 legitimate urgency elements, verifiable

legitimate: Nur noch 3 Termine diese Woche frei

criteria.description: Free value given before asking for commitment
howToCheck: Is there a lead magnet or free resource?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Reciprocity - giving first creates obligation to reciprocate
criteria.passCriteria: At least 1 no-strings-attached value offer

criteria.description: Value perception established before price reveal
howToCheck: Is the full value communicated before price?
Price in context of value gained?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Anchoring effect - first number influences perception of subsequent numbers
criteria.passCriteria: Value established before price; comparison anchor present

examples.good: Normale Tankkosten: 150/Monat. Mit eigener Wallbox: nur 50/Monat. Ersparnis: 1.200/Jahr. Investition: ab 1.499.

categories.name: Visual-First Design
categories.description: Images and visuals communicate faster than text

criteria.description: Offer understood through visuals alone in 3 seconds
howToCheck: Show page to someone for 3 seconds, then hide
Ask: What do they sell/do? Could they answer?
Do images tell the story without text?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Picture superiority effect - images processed 60,000x faster than text
criteria.passCriteria: Untrained viewer can identify business type and offer in 3 seconds

criteria.description: Visual content dominates, text supports
howToCheck: Estimate % of viewport that is images vs text
Images are large enough to be meaningful?
Text blocks broken up by visuals?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Visual content increases engagement by 80% and recall by 65%
criteria.passCriteria: 60%+ of content area is visual; max 3 lines of text between images

criteria.description: Icons accelerate understanding of features/benefits
howToCheck: Are key benefits shown with icons?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Icons serve as visual shorthand, reducing cognitive load
criteria.passCriteria: All major features/benefits have relevant icons; consistent icon style

criteria.description: Key numbers pop and are easily scannable
howToCheck: Are important numbers large and prominent?
Stats in trust bar or hero?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Numbers provide concrete proof; large numbers create impact
criteria.passCriteria: 3+ stats prominently displayed; at least 1 above fold
failIndicators: Stats same size as body text

criteria.description: Visual proof of results/outcomes
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Visual proof of transformation creates desire and reduces skepticism
criteria.passCriteria: At least 1 before/after or transformation visual present

categories.name: Information Architecture
categories.description: Right information at the right time in the right order

criteria.description: Information revealed in appropriate sequence as user scrolls
howToCheck: Does page follow: Problem > Solution > Proof > Action?
Is complex info hidden until needed (accordions, tabs)?
Does each section answer natural next question?
Can user get deeper if they want?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Reducing upfront complexity increases engagement; reveal depth progressively
criteria.passCriteria: Logical flow; complex details in expandable sections; each scroll reveals next logical step

criteria.description: Benefits stated before features; outcomes before methods
howToCheck: Does headline state a benefit, not a feature?
Each feature tied to customer outcome?
So what? test on each claim
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Customers buy outcomes, not products. Benefits create emotional connection.
criteria.passCriteria: Every feature has explicit benefit; headline is benefit-focused
failIndicators: We do X vs You get Y

examples.benefit: Laden Sie uber Nacht - morgens ist Ihr Auto voll, wahrend Sie schlafen

criteria.description: Common objections addressed before they become blockers
howToCheck: Are price concerns addressed before/near CTA?
Is FAQ visible without deep scrolling?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Unaddressed objections create friction; preemptive answers build trust
criteria.passCriteria: Top 3 objections addressed; FAQ before final CTA
commonGermanObjections: Was wenn etwas schief geht? (Garantien zeigen)

criteria.description: Contacting the business is as easy as possible
howToCheck: How many clicks to reach contact form?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Every additional step loses 20% of potential conversions
criteria.passCriteria: Contact possible in 1 click; phone prominent; form has <5 required fields

criteria.description: Content optimized for scanning, not deep reading
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: 79% of users scan; only 16% read word-by-word (Nielsen)
criteria.passCriteria: No paragraph >3 lines; lists as bullets; subheadings every 300px

criteria.description: One obvious main action; supporting actions subordinate
howToCheck: Is there ONE clear primary CTA?
Is primary visually dominant (size, color, contrast)?
Are secondary CTAs (phone, email) visually lighter?
Would a stranger know what to click?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Single clear action reduces decision paralysis; hierarchy guides choice
criteria.passCriteria: 1 primary CTA per viewport; obviously more prominent than alternatives

criteria.description: CTA button is the most visually prominent element
howToCheck: Does CTA color differ from other elements?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Von Restorff effect - distinctive elements are remembered and noticed
criteria.passCriteria: CTA is most contrasting element; visible in squint test; >44px tap target

criteria.description: CTA text describes what happens next in user's benefit terms
howToCheck: Does CTA start with action verb?
Does it describe outcome, not just action?
Is it specific to this page/offer?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Specific, benefit-oriented CTAs outperform generic by 90%+
criteria.passCriteria: Verb + benefit format; specific to offer

criteria.description: Small text near CTA that reduces friction
howToCheck: Is there text below CTA reducing risk?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Micro-copy addresses last-second objections at the decision point
criteria.passCriteria: Micro-copy beneath every form CTA; addresses top anxiety
examples: Ihre Daten sind bei uns sicher

criteria.description: CTAs appear at logical points throughout the page
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Different users convert at different points; always make action accessible
criteria.passCriteria: CTA visible every 2 scrolls; sticky on mobile; final CTA section

categories.name: Trust Architecture
categories.description: Building credibility and reducing perceived risk

criteria.description: Immediate credibility indicators visible without scrolling
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Trust established in first 50ms; early signals prevent bounce
criteria.passCriteria: 2+ trust signals visible above fold on both desktop and mobile

criteria.description: Testimonials feel real and verifiable
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Specificity = credibility; vague praise is suspicious
criteria.passCriteria: Testimonials have full name, photo, specific detail, verifiable source

examples.authentic: Thomas M., Munchen-Schwabing: 'Die Wallbox wurde innerhalb von 3 Tagen installiert. Besonders beeindruckt hat mich die saubere Kabelverlegung.'

criteria.description: Professional qualifications prominently displayed
howToCheck: Mentioned in text as well as visual?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Third-party validation is more trustworthy than self-claims
criteria.passCriteria: All relevant certifications displayed with official logos

criteria.description: Clear differentiation from competitors
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Differentiation reduces comparison shopping; unique = memorable
criteria.passCriteria: 3+ unique differentiators clearly communicated

criteria.description: Guarantees and assurances that reduce perceived risk
howToCheck: What happens if something goes wrong?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Risk reversal shifts burden from buyer to seller, reducing friction
criteria.passCriteria: At least 1 clear guarantee; warranty terms visible
examples: Nicht zufrieden? Wir kommen kostenlos zuruck

criteria.description: All interactive elements easily tappable with thumb
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Frustrated users leave; easy interaction = higher conversion
criteria.passCriteria: All interactive elements 44px+; 8px+ spacing; CTA in thumb zone

criteria.description: Most important content visible first on mobile
howToCheck: Hero content not truncated on mobile?
Key info not hidden in collapsed sections?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Mobile users are more task-focused; surface key info immediately
criteria.passCriteria: Value prop, CTA, and phone visible in first mobile viewport

criteria.description: Page loads quickly on mobile networks
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: 53% of mobile users abandon sites that take >3 seconds to load
criteria.passCriteria: Mobile PageSpeed score >80; LCP <2.5s

criteria.description: Primary action always accessible during scroll
howToCheck: Is there a sticky header or footer CTA?
Does it disappear when scrolling up (optional)?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Persistent CTA reduces friction; action always one tap away
criteria.passCriteria: Sticky CTA bar with phone/WhatsApp; not more than 60px height

criteria.description: Phone number works with one tap
howToCheck: Phone number wrapped in tel: link?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Removing steps to call = more calls. 60% of mobile searches result in calls.
criteria.passCriteria: Phone number clickable; opens dialer; visible in hero and sticky

categories.name: German Local Business Specifics
categories.description: Cultural and regulatory considerations for German market

criteria.description: Consistent formal/informal address throughout
howToCheck: Is the entire page consistent in Sie or Du?
Does the tone match the audience?
Forms match the rest of the page?
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Inconsistency in address feels unprofessional; breaks trust
criteria.passCriteria: 100% consistent throughout all copy, forms, and CTAs
failIndicators: Formal in copy, informal in CTA

criteria.description: Clear local presence and service area
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Local businesses are trusted more; proximity = reliability
criteria.passCriteria: City in H1; service area on homepage; local references present
examples: Wir kommen zu Ihnen nach Schwabing, Bogenhausen, Haidhausen...

criteria.description: Culture-specific credibility signals
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Germans particularly value formal qualifications and guarantees
criteria.passCriteria: At least 2 German-specific trust markers displayed

criteria.description: Privacy compliance visibly communicated
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: DSGVO compliance is expected; non-compliance = unprofessional
criteria.passCriteria: Cookie banner present; privacy policy linked; form privacy note; Impressum in footer

criteria.description: Proper German without translation artifacts
criteria.psychologicalPrinciple: Language errors signal carelessness or foreign origin; reduces trust
criteria.passCriteria: Native-level German throughout; no translation artifacts

howToScore: 2. Mark as Pass (full points), Partial (half points), or Fail (0 points)
3. Weight by priority: Critical = 10pts, High = 5pts, Medium = 2pts
scoringGuide.prioritization: Address all Critical items first, then High, then Medium

items: [ ] 3-second test: Can you understand the offer?
[ ] Is there ONE clear CTA above the fold?
quickAuditChecklist.scoring: 8-10 pass = good, 5-7 pass = needs work, <5 pass = poor
